title: P86-1011

sentences.text: We examine the relationship between the two grammatical formalisms : Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars .
We briefly investigate the weak equivalence of the two formalisms .
We then turn to a discussion comparing the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms .

Entity-the_relationship_between_the_two_.label: the relationship between the two grammatical formalisms
aliases: the relationship between the two grammatical formalisms
Entity-the_relationship_between_the_two_.description: The relationship between the two grammatical formalisms refers to the comparative analysis of Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars, focusing on their weak equivalence and linguistic expressiveness.

mentions.local_name: the relationship between the two grammatical formalisms

Entity-the_two_formalism.label: the two formalisms
Entity-the_two_formalism.description: The two formalisms refer to Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars, which are grammatical frameworks examined for their weak equivalence and linguistic expressiveness.

Entity-the_linguistic_expressiveness_of_.label: the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms
aliases: the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms
Entity-the_linguistic_expressiveness_of_.description: The linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms refers to the comparative analysis of the capabilities of Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars in representing linguistic structures.

mentions.local_name: the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms

Entity-head_grammar.label: Head Grammars
Entity-head_grammar.description: Head Grammars are a type of grammatical formalism used in linguistic theory, which are compared to Tree Adjoining Grammars in terms of their weak equivalence and linguistic expressiveness.

Entity-weak_equivalence.label: weak equivalence
aliases: the weak equivalence of the two formalisms
Entity-weak_equivalence.description: Weak equivalence refers to a theoretical property that assesses the relationship between two grammatical formalisms, specifically Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars, in terms of their ability to generate the same language or structures.

mentions.local_name: the weak equivalence of the two formalisms

Entity-tree_adjoining_grammar.label: Tree Adjoining Grammars
Entity-tree_adjoining_grammar.description: Tree Adjoining Grammars are a type of formal grammar used in computational linguistics and natural language processing that allows for the generation and analysis of syntactic structures through the combination of tree structures.

Entity-a_discussion.label: a discussion
Entity-a_discussion.description: a discussion refers to an analytical examination and comparison of the linguistic expressiveness of Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars within the context of their weak equivalence.

Entity-formalism.label: formalisms
Entity-formalism.description: Formalisms are structured systems or frameworks used to represent and analyze concepts, often in mathematics or theoretical disciplines, that provide a formal language and rules for reasoning about various phenomena.

Entity-linguistic_expressiveness.label: linguistic expressiveness
Entity-linguistic_expressiveness.description: Linguistic expressiveness refers to the capacity of a language or formalism to convey a wide range of meanings, nuances, and subtleties in communication.

summary: We examine the relationship between the two grammatical formalisms : Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars . We briefly investigate the weak equivalence of the two formalisms . We then turn to a discussion comparing the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms .

Predicate-examines_the_relationship_with.label: examines the relationship with
Predicate-examines_the_relationship_with.description: The predicate 'examines the relationship with' indicates an analytical or evaluative process where the subject is investigating, assessing, or exploring the connections, interactions, or dependencies between itself and the object. This involves a detailed consideration of how the two entities relate to each other, including their similarities, differences, and the implications of their relationship.

Predicate-involves.label: involves
Predicate-involves.description: The predicate 'involves' indicates a connection or relationship where the subject encompasses or requires the object as a necessary component or aspect. It suggests that the subject cannot be fully understood or realized without considering the object, highlighting the integral role the object plays in the context of the subject.

Predicate-compares_with.label: compares with
Predicate-compares_with.description: The predicate 'compares with' establishes a relationship between two subjects, indicating that they are being evaluated or analyzed in relation to each other. This comparison may involve examining similarities, differences, advantages, or disadvantages, and is often used to highlight distinctions or to assess the relative merits of the subjects in question.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a possession or association between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the object. It establishes a direct link where the subject is seen as the holder or bearer of the qualities, attributes, or relationships described by the object.

Predicate-investigate.label: investigate
Predicate-investigate.description: The predicate 'investigate' denotes the action of examining, exploring, or analyzing a subject in order to uncover information, understand its properties, or determine its relationships with other entities. In the context of the triple, it signifies that the subject is being scrutinized or studied in relation to the object, which may be the same or a different entity, to gain insights or draw conclusions about its nature or behavior.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' serves as a linking verb that establishes an identity or equivalence between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject can be defined or characterized by the object, suggesting that they are fundamentally the same in some respect or that the subject belongs to the category represented by the object.

Predicate-investigates.label: investigates
Predicate-investigates.description: The predicate 'investigates' denotes an action where the subject conducts a systematic examination or inquiry into the object, which represents a specific concept, phenomenon, or relationship. This action implies a search for understanding, analysis, or evaluation, often with the aim of uncovering insights, establishing connections, or determining the validity of the object in relation to the subject.

Predicate-examines.label: examines
Predicate-examines.description: The predicate 'examines' indicates an analytical action where the subject engages in a detailed investigation or study of the object. It implies a process of observation, consideration, or scrutiny aimed at understanding, evaluating, or interpreting the characteristics, properties, or dynamics of the object in relation to the subject.

Predicate-compares_in_terms_of.label: compares in terms of
Predicate-compares_in_terms_of.description: The predicate 'compares in terms of' establishes a relationship where the subject is evaluated or assessed against the object based on specific criteria or attributes. It indicates that the subject is being analyzed to determine similarities, differences, or relative standing concerning the characteristics represented by the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or subset of a more general category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a wider range of concepts or entities than the subject, thereby situating the subject within a broader context.
